IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
MSP unmarked vehicle Q-41 is equipped with a mobile recording device. Body worn camera worn and operational.

• Defendant: Jermaine Anthony Matthews
• Date of Birth: 07/17/1971
• Date of Arrest: 10/21/2023
• Time of Arrest: 0238 hours
• DUI #: 23-249

CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING
* Trained in administering standardized field sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.


VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)
On Saturday, October 21, 2023 at approximately 0216 hours, I, Trooper Webb of the Maryland State Police – College Park Barrack was on routine patrol in my unmarked MSP vehicle Q-41 in lane three of the east bound 50 prior to Maryland 197.  At this time, I observed a black Cadillac bearing District of Columbia registration JC4086. I observed this black Cadillac in lane four directly in front of me cross over the dotted white traffic line. He would cross these dotted lines from lane four to lane three four times, each time he crossed over was by a tire width and he would stay over the line for a few seconds. I activated my emergency equipment and conducted a traffic stop on the vehicle.  After turning on my lights, the vehicle pulled off the roadway to the right and onto the shoulder and came to a complete stop.  After the vehicle came to a complete stop I made contact with the driver.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2)
I made contact with the operator via the passenger side window and upon my approach I immediately smelled the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the interior of the vehicle.  I gave the driver my rank, name, ID number, agency and I informed the driver the reason for the stop. I also advised him the stop was being audibly/visually recorded. I requested his license and registration card.  The driver was identified by his Maryland driver’s license as Jermaine Anthony Matthews. I asked Matthews where he was coming from and he stated, “In DC, my daughter just had a baby.” I asked Matthews how much he had to drink and he stated, "One beer."  As I spoke to Matthews, I intentionally observed his eyes to be glassy and bloodshot with a gazed look and noticed his head and body movements were slow and lethargic.  I returned to my patrol vehicle and conducted routine checks on Matthews.

I approached the vehicle again and requested Matthews exit his vehicle and walk to the front of his vehicle, to which he complied.  I continued to speak with Matthews outside of his vehicle and as Matthews spoke, I smelled the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person. I informed Matthews that I wanted him to perform field sobriety tests.

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3)
The evaluation was performed on the shoulder of the highway. The surface was dry, level, and free from any obvious debris. The weather was clear and approximately 55 degrees. Lighting conditions consisted of street lamps, patrol vehicle headlamps, spotlight, and my flashlight. My patrol vehicle’s forward emergency lights were deactivated during all three tests. Matthews appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible injuries. 

I asked Matthews the following questions: 

Injuries – Knees and hips were bad from his military service.
Medication – No
Medical Conditions – No
Glasses - No

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed)
The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The tip of my pointer finger was used as the test's stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Matthews's eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. Matthews's pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking and no resting Nystagmus was observed. He was positioned in a manner to ensure the headlights of passing traffic would not interfere with the test results. I asked Matthews if he understood the instructions and he stated "yes." 

1.) Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes
2.) Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes
3.) Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Present in both eyes

WALK AND TURN (4/8 clues observed)
Prior to Matthews performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Matthews was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe. Matthews was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his side and to remain in the position until told to begin. Matthews was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight line touching heel to toe on every step. Matthews was to keep his hands flat at his side, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Matthews was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, and to take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to turn completely around. Matthews was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. Matthews was instructed that once he began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his side, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud. I asked Matthews if he understood the test and he stated, "Yes".

Instructional Stage: 
1.) Feet broke apart for entirety of instructions.
  
Walking Stage (1st Nine):
1.) Took 10 steps instead of the instructed 9 steps.
2.) Missed heel to toe by more than an inch on step 8. 

Walking Stage (2nd Nine):
1.) Took 10 steps instead of the instructed 9 steps.

Turn: 
1.) Improper - turned in one fluid motion to the left.

ONE LEG STAND (0/4 clues observed)
Prior to Matthews performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Matthews was instructed to stand with his heels together and hands down by his sides while the instructions were given and during the test. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. I asked Matthews if he understood the test and he stated "yes." 

Instructional Stage: 
1.) Nothing to report.

Balance and Count Stage: 

Seconds 0-10:
1.) Nothing to report.

Seconds 11-20:
1.) Nothing to report.

Seconds 21-30:
1.) Nothing to report.

Matthews submitted to a preliminary breath test with a .13 BrAC result.

ARREST
Based on the following, I had reason to believe Matthews was driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:

* Swerving vehicle multiple times.
* Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from vehicle.
* Slow and lethargic head and body movements.
* Eyes glassy and bloodshot with a gazed look.
* Admitted to consuming 1 beer.
* Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person.
* My observed signs of impairment as he performed field sobriety tests.
* PBT result of .13.

I arrested Matthews for driving under the influence of alcohol at approximately 0238 hours and he was placed in the front passenger seat of my patrol vehicle and transported to the Maryland State Police – College Park Barrack for processing. Once at the barrack, I played the English audio DR-15 Advice of Rights form to Matthews in its entirety.  At the conclusion of the form, Matthews verbally advised that he would not submit to the intoximeter test and signed the form indicating the same. 

20-MINUTE OBSERVATION PERIOD:
I conducted the observation period on Matthews in its entirety starting with his time of arrest. I escorted Matthews into the arrest processing room and remained in his custody until the time of test. Matthews's mouth was checked and no foreign objects or piercings were observed. 

Matthews was given all copies of pertinent paperwork and later released to his wife. Matthews was polite and cooperative throughout the process.

All events occurred in Prince Georges County, Maryland.

Case closed by arrest.
